Simulation

Source: vignettes/simulation.Rmd
simulation.Rmd

This vignette explains how to simulate longitudinal clinical disease progression datasets from each of the models in pmrm. For details about the models, including definitions of all the notation used below, please see the “Models” vignette.

Residuals

The user supplies the J×JJ \times J residual covariance matrix Σ\Sigma1. Independently for each patient ii (i=1,…,Ii = 1, \ldots, I), the package simulates a vector of patient-specific residuals from a multivariate normal distribution:

[ei1⋮eiJ]∼MVN(0,Σ) \begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} e_{i1} \\ \vdots \\ e_{iJ} \end{bmatrix} \sim \text{MVN} \left (0, \Sigma \right) \end{aligned}

Covariates

Each column of the covariate adjustment model matrix WW is constructed by simulating independent draws from a Normal(0, 1) distribution and then subtracting the mean. The columns of WW are independent and centered at zero. The user chooses the fixed effect vector γ\gamma to generate data.

Continuous time

As previously mentioned, time j=1j = 1 denotes the baseline visit, and so ti1=0t_{i1} = 0 for i=1,…,Ii = 1, \ldots, I. For j>1j > 1, we simulate each observation time tijt_{ij} as follows:

tij*∼Normal(tj*,τ2)tij=|tij*| \begin{aligned} t_{ij}^* &\sim \text{Normal}(t_j^*, \tau^2) \\ t_{ij} &= |t_{ij}^*| \end{aligned}

where t1*t_1^* (j=1,…,Jj = 1, \ldots, J) are user-specified visit times (which could be different from the knots ξ\xi) and τ2\tau^2 is a user-specified variance.

Splines

The knot vector ξ=(ξ1,…,ξS)\xi = (\xi_1, \dots, \xi_S) and corresponding outcome vector α=(α1,…,αS)\alpha = (\alpha_1, \ldots, \alpha_S) uniquely determine a fitted spline. Both vectors are supplied by the user. We compute f(t|ξ,α)f(t | \xi, \alpha) using the function provided by RTMB::splinefun().

Proportional decline outcomes

For the proportional decline model, we use the spline basis to calculate the value mijm_{ij} of the mean function for each simulated continuous time point tijt_{ij}:

mij=f(tij|ξ,α) \begin{aligned} m_{ij} &= f(t_{ij} | \xi, \alpha) \end{aligned}

The user supplies values for parameters θ1,…,θK−1\theta_1, \ldots, \theta_{K - 1}. This gives us known values for all of β1,…,βK\beta_1, \ldots, \beta_K. We calculate yijy_{ij} as follows:

yij=(1−βb(i))(mij−mi1)+mi1+Wiγ+eij \begin{aligned} y_{ij} &= (1 - \beta_{b(i)}) \left (m_{ij} - m_{i1} \right ) + m_{i1} + W_{i}\gamma + e_{ij} \end{aligned}

The output dataset includes simulated clinical outcomes yijy_{ij}, simulated observed times tijt_{ij}, the columns of WW, the values mijm_{ij} of the mean function, the evaluated values hs(tij|ξ)h_s(t_{ij} | \xi) of the spline basis functions, and the residuals eije_{ij}.

Non-proportional slowing outcomes

For the non-proportional slowing model, the user supplies the values of true parameters θ11,…,θ(K−1)(J−1)\theta_{11}, \dots, \theta_{(K - 1)(J - 1)}. This gives us a known value of βkj\beta_{kj} for k=1,…,Kk = 1, \ldots, K and j=1,…,Jj = 1, \ldots, J. Recall that uiju_{ij} is the effective time point along the disease progression trajectory of patient ii at visit jj:

uij=(1−βb(i)j)tij \begin{aligned} u_{ij} = (1 - \beta_{b(i)j}) t_{ij} \end{aligned}

We calculate each value mijm_{ij} of the mean function by evaluating the spline at uiju_{ij} instead of tijt_{ij}:

mij=f(uij|ξ,α) \begin{aligned} m_{ij} &= f(u_{ij} | \xi, \alpha) \end{aligned}

Then, yijy_{ij} for the non-proportional slowing model is:

yij=mij+Wiγ+eij \begin{aligned} y_{ij} &= m_{ij} + W_{i}\gamma + e_{ij} \end{aligned}

The output dataset includes simulated clinical outcomes yijy_{ij}, simulated observed times tijt_{ij}, the corresponding effective times uiju_{ij}, the columns of WW, the values mijm_{ij} of the mean function evaluated at the effective times uiju_{ij}, the values hs(uij|ξ)h_s(u_{ij} | \xi) of the spline basis functions evaluated at the effective times, and the residuals eije_{ij}.
